JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: The applicants are CARDINAL NORP nationals of NORP ethnic origin . Mr ORG PERSON ( the first applicant ) , was born in DATE and is detained in PERSON prison . Mr PERSON ( the second applicant ) , was born in DATE and is detained in PERSON . They were represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in PERSON . The Government of GPE ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the cases , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The first applicant arrived illegally in GPE from GPE on DATE . He was arrested . He disclosed his identity to NORP authorities in DATE , in the context of proceedings concerning his request for asylum . That request was dismissed by a decision which became final on DATE .
A second request for asylum lodged by the first applicant was also dismissed . The final decision on the issue was given by ORG on DATE .

In the meantime , on DATE and DATE , ORG applied for the first applicant 's extradition . The request was based on the fact that he had been accused of several offences , in particular banditry with aggravating circumstances and attempt on the life of officials of a law - enforcement agency .

The applicant was suspected of taking part , as a member of an organised group , in the killing of CARDINAL agents of ORG in ORG in DATE . In DATE the applicant with the other members of the group had allegedly forced a government official and a different person to give them a firearm , money , gold items and mobile phones .

The letters indicated that the applicant would not be tried by ORG , would enjoy the guarantees of a fair trial including the assistance of counsel , and would not be subjected to treatment contrary to LAW . As to the risk of the death penalty , the letter of DATE indicated that there was a moratorium on that penalty in GPE , that the death penalty would not be imposed on the first applicant and that capital punishment was not provided for the offences imputed to him .

On DATE ORG concluded that the first applicant 's extradition to GPE for the purpose of his criminal prosecution there was inadmissible . The decision stated that there was a risk that the applicant would be ill - treated , that he ran the risk of receiving the death penalty and that he would not be guaranteed a fair trial if extradited . Reference was made to ORG reports of DATE and DATE .
The public prosecutor appealed .

On DATE ORG overturned that decision and held that the applicant 's extradition was admissible . After examining the applicant 's situation in detail , it found no relevant factor preventing his extradition .

In particular , ORG took note of the guarantees given by ORG . As regards the risk of imposition of capital punishment , it analysed the law and practice in GPE and concluded that there existed no real risk that the death penalty would be imposed for the offences imputed to him .

As to the risk that the applicant would be ill - treated , ORG , with reference to the ORG 's practice ( in particular PERSON v. GPE [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , ECHR DATE ... ) and various international materials on the conflict in GPE , noted that its decision on the extradition of a particular person for the purpose of his criminal prosecution could not be exclusively based on the political situation existing in a part of GPE and the fact that the ORG 's actions in that respect had been subjected to international criticism . The decision further stated that GPE was a member ORG and a ORG to the Convention . All persons within its jurisdiction were therefore entitled to seek redress before the ORG as regards alleged breach of their LAW rights by the NORP authorities .

As to the witness PERSON ( see point CARDINAL below ) , whose statements had given rise to the applicant 's prosecution , his alleged ill - treatment was not proof that the applicant would be subjected to treatment incompatible with LAW .
ORG also held that a possible failure by NORP authorities to comply with the guarantees issued by them would undermine the trust of its partners and affect further processing of similar requests .

A refusal to extradite the first applicant would affect the rights of other persons , in particular the relatives of the officers who had been killed , who were entitled to have an effective investigation carried out .

The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint . ORG , to which the case fell to be examined , had a different opinion on the issue from that which ORG had expressed in its decision of DATE in the case of the second applicant ( see point CARDINAL below ) . It therefore submitted the matter to the plenary meeting of ORG with a view to harmonising the positions .
In decision PLz ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ORG ( plenary meeting ) did not accept the proposal by its Fourth ORG to depart from the conclusion which ORG had reached on DATE .

On DATE ORG Fourth Chamber ) decided that ORG had violated the first applicant 's right under LAW by allowing his extradition to GPE . The case was returned to ORG . In its decision ORG ) stated that it did not , in principle , object to the way in which ORG had proceeded . However , there was a need for the case to be examined in the light of the most recent case - law of ORG and all available information . The trustworthiness of the guarantees offered by GPE had also to be addressed in more detail . Reference was made to the fact that the ORG had issued an interim measure in the case .
In an opinion of CARDINAL DATE ORG ( plenary meeting ) noted that in the above decision FAC had disregarded decision PLz ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE .
On DATE ORG again found that the applicant 's extradition to GPE for the purpose of his criminal prosecution there was admissible .

In its decision ORG analysed the first applicant 's case in the light of the ORG 's reasoning in the cases of ORG and Others v. GPE and GPE ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALIII ) , and PERSON v. GPE ( dec . ) , no . CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE ) . It also had regard to other cases , such as GPE and Others v. GPE ( DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL ) ; ORG v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALI ) ; PERSON and Others v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , DATE ) ; and Estamirov and Others v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , DATE ) .

ORG held that various data available internationally containing general information about the use of violence by NORP armed forces against the civilian population of GPE did not prove the existence of a specific risk that the first applicant would be ill - treated if extradited . The applicant himself had not provided any specific information about himself permitting a different conclusion .

With reference to the reasons set out in its decision of DATE ORG again concluded that the guarantees offered by the NORP authorities were sufficient and that it had not been established that the applicant ran a real risk of treatment contrary to LAW . ORG also invoked ORG ) decision of DATE in the case of the second applicant with the same factual background , and decision PLz ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL in which ORG at its plenary meeting had refused to depart from that decision .

On DATE the first applicant lodged a complaint with ORG . He relied on LAW and CARDINAL of the LAW , on an ORG interim recommendation concerning international protection of persons of NORP origin and on a ORG report issued on DATE ( see point CARDINAL below ) . He argued that ORG had disregarded ORG order that his case should be examined in the light of the ORG 's practice , that he would be subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment and that he would not enjoy the guarantees of a fair trial in case of his extradition . As to the last point , he asserted that the principal witness in the criminal proceedings had given a statement against him under torture .

On DATE ORG ( First Chamber ) rejected the complaint as manifestly ill - founded . It found that ORG had duly considered the relevant facts and law , including the practice of the ORG . ORG accepted ORG conclusion according to which it had not been established that the guarantees offered by the NORP authorities were not trustworthy and that the applicant ran a real risk of treatment contrary to LAW in case of his extradition . Finally , ORG held that it lacked the power to address the fairness of criminal proceedings which were pending before the NORP authorities .

In a letter of CARDINAL DATE addressed to the NORP authorities the Deputy Prosecutor General of GPE confirmed the guarantees previously given with regard to the first applicant , including respect for his physical and psychological integrity . The letter indicated that , in case of his conviction and imposition of a prison term , the second applicant would serve his sentence in a federal prison , where the LAW and the NORP Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners are taken into account . ORG to GPE would be informed of the place of the applicant 's detention and NORP diplomatic representatives would be able to visit the first applicant and speak to him without third parties present . The applicant would be provided with sufficient medical care . It was guaranteed that capital punishment would not be applied in respect of the first applicant . Finally , ORG Russian Federation guaranteed that the first applicant would not be prosecuted for his political views or because of his race , religion or nationality .
The second applicant was arrested by NORP border police on DATE . He had no valid travel document and gave his name as PERSON .
On DATE the second applicant applied for asylum in GPE . His request was ultimately dismissed . The final decision was given by ORG on DATE . The decision became final on CARDINAL DATE .
In the meantime , in DATE , the identity of the second applicant was established .

On DATE ORG applied for the second applicant 's extradition . The request was based on the fact that he had been accused of several offences , namely banditry with aggravating circumstances and attempt on the life of officials of a law - enforcement agency . The applicant was suspected of having participated , as a member of an organised group , in the killing of CARDINAL agents of ORG in ORG in DATE .

The above letter and another letter from ORG dated DATE indicated that the applicant would not be tried by ORG , would enjoy the guarantees of a fair trial including the assistance of counsel and that he would not be subjected to treatment contrary to LAW . As to the risk of the death penalty , the letters indicated that there was a moratorium on the death penalty in GPE , that the applicant would not face the death penalty if extradited and that , should the applicant be sentenced to death , the sentence would not be carried out . Reference was made to the fact that GPE had signed LAW No . CARDINAL to the LAW and that under LAW and CARDINAL of LAW on GPE of DATE it had an obligation not to use the death penalty .

The second applicant was placed in preliminary detention with effect from DATE . On DATE the ORG remanded him in custody pending extradition . ORG dismissed the applicant 's complaint against that decision on DATE .
On DATE the ORG found inadmissible the applicant 's extradition to GPE .

On DATE ORG overturned that decision and held that the second applicant 's extradition was admissible . ORG , with reference to documents available , established that the applicant had been involved , as a member of an organised group , in the killing of CARDINAL NORP servicemen in PERSON in DATE . That killing had taken place after the military conflict had ended and it was not therefore an exclusively political or military action within the meaning of the relevant provision of the NORP Code of Criminal Procedure , which prevented the extradition of foreigners in such cases . ORG further noted that GPE was a member ORG and that respect for human rights was permanently monitored .

Finally , ORG considered sufficient the guarantees offered by ORG , which stated that the applicant would not face the death penalty and that such punishment was in any event not carried out in GPE , that he would not be tried by a ORG as well as the undertaking that ORG and CARDINAL of the ORG would be respected in his case .

On DATE the second applicant lodged a complaint with ORG . He relied on LAW . The applicant referred to various reports on the situation in prisons in GPE . In particular , he invoked reports on treatment to which persons of NORP origin suspected of fighting against NORP authorities were subjected . He also invoked the fact that the death penalty had not been formally abolished in GPE .

On DATE ORG ) dismissed the complaint as being manifestly ill - founded . It relied on the reasoning of ORG which it considered relevant and sufficient from the point of view of protecting the applicant 's rights under LAW .

In a letter of CARDINAL DATE addressed to the NORP authorities the Deputy Prosecutor General of GPE confirmed the guarantees previously given with regard to the second applicant , including respect for his physical and psychological integrity . The letter indicated that , if he was convicted and given a prison sentence , the second applicant would serve his sentence in a federal prison , where the LAW and the NORP Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners are taken into account . ORG to GPE would be informed of the place of the second applicant 's detention and NORP diplomatic representatives would be able to visit the second applicant and speak to him without the presence of third persons . The second applicant would be provided with sufficient medical care . It was guaranteed that capital punishment would not be applied in respect of the second applicant . Finally , ORG Russian Federation guaranteed that the second applicant would not be prosecuted for his political views or because of his race , religion or nationality .
The applicants maintained that criminal proceedings against them had been instituted on the basis of statements of PERSON , which had been extracted under torture .

Mr PERSON , while being questioned in GPE on DATE , had admitted involvement in a number of offences which he had committed as a member of an organised group . Among those offences reference was made to the killing of CARDINAL members of the special units of ORG . Those persons had been shot after members of the group had stopped their car on a road . Mr PERSON indicated the applicants as having been among the accomplices .

Subsequently Mr PERSON , with the assistance of an advocate , lodged a criminal complaint , arguing that his defence rights had been infringed after his extradition from GPE and that he had been subjected to treatment incompatible with LAW while he was being questioned and detained in GPE . The complaint was dismissed by the prosecuting authorities . On DATE ORG of ORG quashed the above decision to dismiss Mr PERSON 's criminal complaint . The court noted that the prosecuting authorities had not examined all the relevant facts and that the origin of several documented injuries sustained by Mr PERSON had not been established . The court ordered the prosecutor to review the decision to dismiss Mr PERSON 's criminal complaint .
In DATE Mr PERSON lodged an application with the ORG . The proceedings are pending ( application no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

In their observations of CARDINAL DATE the applicants referred to the case of Mr PERSON who had unsuccessfully applied for asylum in GPE in DATE . The applicants submitted that , after his expulsion , Mr PERSON had spent DATE in a prison in GPE and that he had been tortured and ill - treated . Subsequently he had been transferred to the GPE detention facility in PERSON , where he had been repeatedly tortured . With the help of his relatives and the payment of a ransom he received a conditional prison term only and was released .
The applicants indicated that they would submit a written statement by Mr PERSON , together with the relevant medical reports .
No such documents have been submitted .

In the above case Rule DATE was applied in the Third Section of the Court to suspend the NORP applicant 's extradition to GPE , where he faced criminal charges . That measure was lifted following the receipt of assurances by ORG that the applicant would not be condemned to the death penalty or to an irreducible life sentence , or detained in conditions which were contrary to LAW . There was also a guarantee that monitoring of compliance with that guarantee was to be ensured through the NORP diplomatic representation in GPE .
ORG ) declared the application inadmissible on CARDINAL DATE .

According to a press release by ORG of DATE , PERSON , accused of taking part in an attack on government buildings in ORG in DATE , had been released by the NORP authorities without charge on DATE , after DATE in pre - trial detention . The press release further stated that “ according to PERSON , he was tortured for DATE and then released without charge ” .

According to third - party comments by the Government of GPE , the criminal proceedings against Mr PERSON had ended following an amnesty . Such action was permissible under the NORP law subject to admission of guilt by the accused person .

Before ORG the applicants relied , inter alia , on a press release by ORG of DATE entitled “ GPE : Prosecute Rights Violations in LOC ” . In it reference is made to the fact that the ORG adopted CARDINAL judgments holding GPE responsible for serious violations of human rights in GPE . ORG , ORG and the NORP ORG called on the NORP government to ratify LAW No . DATE , to re - open investigations in those cases where the ORG had concluded that prior investigations were inadequate , to undertake a thorough review and revision of domestic legislation and regulations regarding the use of force by military or security forces to ensure their compliance with human rights law and to carry out an in - depth inquiry into the conduct of investigations of abuses committed by military servicemen , police , and intelligence officials and other forces in GPE .
